     115           0 : void repr_for_ptr_to_data_member_constant(a_constant_ptr   constant, 
     116             :                                           a_targ_ptrdiff_t *delta)
     117             : /*
     118             : Determine the lowered representation of the indicated pointer-to-data-member
     119             : constant, and return information about it in *delta.
     120             : */

     123           0 :   a_targ_ptrdiff_t offset;
     124             : 
     125           0 :   check_assertion(constant->kind == (a_constant_repr_kind)ck_ptr_to_member &&
     126             :                   !constant->variant.ptr_to_member.is_function_ptr);
     127           0 :   field = constant->variant.ptr_to_member.variant.field;
     128             :   /* If non-NULL use the field offset. */
     129           0 :   if (field != NULL) {
     130             :     /* Determine the offset of the field within the class. */
     131             :     /* If the field is a member of an anonymous union, add in the offset of

     144           0 :         check_assertion(!is_union_type(field_class) || field->offset == 0);
     145           0 :         check_assertion(field_sym != NULL);
     146           0 :         field_sym = field_sym->variant.field.anonymous_parent_object;

     148             :                         field_sym->kind == (a_symbol_kind)sk_field);
     149           0 :         field = field_sym->variant.field.ptr;
     150           0 :         continue;
     151             :       } else {

     163             :     offset += 1;

     165             :   } else {
     166             :     /* NULL pointer to data member. */
     167             : #if !IA64_ABI
     168             :     /* Represent NULL as 0. */
     169             :     offset = 0;
     170             : #else /* IA64_ABI */
     171             :     /* Represent NULL as -1. */
     172             :     offset = -1;
     173             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */

     177             : 
     178             : 
     179           0 : void repr_for_ptr_to_member_function_constant(a_constant_ptr   constant,
     180             :                                               a_targ_ptrdiff_t *delta,
     181             :                                               a_targ_ptrdiff_t *idx,
     182             :                                               a_routine_ptr    *func,
     183             :                                               a_targ_ptrdiff_t *offset)
     184             : /*
     185             : Determine the lowered representation of the indicated pointer-to-member
     186             : function constant, and return information about it in *delta, *idx,
     187             : *func, and *offset.  Those values fill the fields of the mptr structure:
     188             : *delta for the "d" field, *idx for the "i" field, and one of
     189             : *func or *offset for the "f" field.
     190             : 
     191             : For the Cfront-like ABI:
     192             :   *delta is the "this" adjustment to be made.
     193             :   *idx is 0 for NULL, -1 for a non-virtual function, and otherwise
     194             :     is the index number of the virtual function in the virtual
     195             :     function table.
     196             :   *func is the function, for the non-virtual case, NULL otherwise.
     197             :   *offset is the offset of the virtual function pointer in the class,
     198             :     or 0 if the function is non-virtual.
     199             : 
     200             : For the IA-64 ABI:
     201             :   *delta is the "this" adjustment to be made.
     202             :   *idx is not used.
     203             :   *func is the function, for the non-virtual case, NULL otherwise.
     204             :   *offset is the offset of the entry for the virtual function in
     205             :     the virtual function table (in bytes), or 0 for the non-virtual
     206             :     case.
     207             :   A NULL pointer has *delta == 0, *func == NULL, and *offset == 0.
     208             :   Either *delta or *offset has the low-order bit indicating whether
     209             :     the function is virtual, depending on
     210             :     targ_ia64_abi_use_variant_ptr_to_member_function_repr.
     211             : */
     212             : {
     213           0 :   a_routine_ptr routine;
     214             : 
     215           0 :   check_assertion(constant->kind == (a_constant_repr_kind)ck_ptr_to_member &&
     216             :                   constant->variant.ptr_to_member.is_function_ptr);
     217           0 :   routine = constant->variant.ptr_to_member.variant.routine;
     218             :   /* The first field is the delta value, the offset of the class of the
     219             :      routine relative to the class pointed to by the pointer-to-member. */
     220           0 :   if (routine == NULL) {
     221             :     /* For a NULL ptr-to-member, delta is zero. */
     222           0 :     *delta = 0;
     223             :   } else {
     224           0 :     *delta = pm_cast_offset(constant);
     225             : #if IA64_ABI && DO_IL_LOWERING
     226             :     if (targ_ia64_abi_use_variant_ptr_to_member_function_repr) {
     227             :       /* In the IA-64 ABI, the low-order bit indicates whether the function
     228             :          is virtual.  This is in the variant of the ABI for architectures
     229             :          where the address of a function can have the least-significant bit
     230             :          set. */
     231             :       *delta = *delta * 2 + (routine->is_virtual ? 1 : 0);
     232             :     }  /* if */
     233             : #endif /* IA64_ABI && DO_IL_LOWERING */
     234             :   }  /* if */
     235             :   /* The second field is
     236             :        0 for a NULL pointer;
     237             :        an index into the virtual function table (>0) is the function is
     238             :          virtual;
     239             :        -1 if the function is non-virtual.
     240             :   */
     241             : #if !IA64_ABI
     242             :   if (routine == NULL) {
     243             :     /* For a NULL ptr-to-member, index is zero. */
     244             :     *idx = 0;
     245             :   } else if (!routine->is_virtual) {
     246             :     /* For a non-virtual function, index is -1. */
     247             :     *idx = (-1);
     248             :   } else {
     249             :     /* For a virtual function, index is the index in the virtual function
     250             :        table.  No "+1" to reserve the value zero for NULL pointers is
     251             :        needed, because the indices start with 1. */
     252             :     *idx = routine->virtual_function_number;
     253             :   }  /* if */
     254             : #else /* IA64_ABI */
     255             :   /* This field is unused in the IA64 ABI. */
     256           0 :   *idx = 0;
     257             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
     258             :   /* The third field is
     259             :        NULL for a null pointer;
     260             :        the offset of the virtual function table pointer in the class of
     261             :          the routine if the function is virtual;
     262             :        a pointer to the function if the function is non-virtual.
     263             :   */
     264           0 :   *offset = 0;
     265           0 :   if (routine == NULL) {
     266             :     /* For a NULL ptr-to-member, *func == NULL, *offset == 0. */
     267           0 :     *func = NULL;
     268           0 :   } else if (!routine->is_virtual) {
     269             :     /* For a non-virtual function, *func points to the routine. */
     270           0 :     *func = routine;
     271             :   } else {
     272             : #if !IA64_ABI
     273             :     /* For a virtual function, the offset of the virtual function table
     274             :        pointer in the class of the routine is returned in *offset,
     275             :        *func == NULL. */
     276             :     a_type_ptr class_type = parent_class_of(routine);
     277             :     check_assertion_str(class_type->variant.class_struct_union.
     278             :                                                          any_virtual_functions,
     279             :    "repr_for_ptr_to_member_function_constant: class has no virtual functions");
     280             :     *offset = class_type_supp(class_type)->virtual_function_info_offset;
     281             : #else /* IA64_ABI */
     282             :     /* In the IA-64 ABI, the offset is the virtual function table offset
     283             :        in bytes of the function. */
     284           0 :     *offset = routine->virtual_function_number * vtbl_entry_size();
     285             : #if DO_IL_LOWERING
     286             :     if (!targ_ia64_abi_use_variant_ptr_to_member_function_repr) {
     287             :       /* The low-order bit is 1 to indicate a virtual function. */
     288             :       if (routine->is_virtual) *offset |= 1;
     289             :     }  /* if */
     290             : #endif /* DO_IL_LOWERING */
     291             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
     292           0 :     *func = NULL;
     293             :   }  /* if */
     294           0 : }  /* repr_for_ptr_to_member_function_constant */
     295             : 
     296             : 
     297             : #if DEBUG && DO_IL_LOWERING

     302             :                 allocated_name_string_length,

     304             : #endif /* DEBUG && DO_IL_LOWERING */

     413             : void db_context_stack(void)

     427             : 
     428             : a_boolean il_lowering_needed(void)
     429             : /*
     430             : Return TRUE if IL lowering is needed.  IL lowering is only needed in
     431             : this compilation if the source language is C++, there are no errors, and
     432             : lowering hasn't been suppressed.  Note that this function considers
     433             : only C++ lowering; there is also lowering done for C99 and GNU C,
     434             : but this routine does not indicate that.
     435             : */
     436             : {
     437             :   a_boolean needed = (C_dialect == C_dialect_cplusplus &&
     438             :                       !suppress_il_lowering &&
     439             :                       total_errors == 0);
     440             :   return needed;
     441             : }  /* il_lowering_needed */
     442             : 
     443             : 
     444             : /*
     445             : Macro used to test for crossing over into the file scope, i.e., a
     446             : reference to a file-scope memory region entity from somewhere in a
     447             : function scope memory region.
     448             : */
     449             : #define crossing_into_file_scope(entry_ptr)                           \
     450             :   (!lowering_file_scope && in_file_scope((char *)(entry_ptr)))
     451             :

     501             : static void lower_boolean_controlling_expr(an_expr_node_ptr expr,

     503             : static void lower_related_class_cast(an_expr_node_ptr node,
     504             :                                      a_boolean        assume_expr_is_non_null);
     505             : static void change_result_type_of_operator_returning_bool(
     506             :                                                         an_expr_node_ptr expr);
     507             : static void adjust_bool_operation_types(an_expr_node_ptr expr,
     508             :                                         a_boolean        *p_adjusted,
     509             :                                         a_boolean        see_if_possible);
     510             : static void lower_pm_comparison(an_expr_node_ptr expr,
     511             :                                 a_boolean        operand1_lowered);
     512             : static void do_scope_namespace_member_promotion(a_scope_ptr scope);
     513             : static void promote_static_variable_out_of_function(
     514             :                                                a_variable_ptr variable,
     515             :                                                a_scope_ptr    scope,
     516             :                                                a_routine_ptr  routine);
     517             : #if GNU_FUNCTION_MULTIVERSIONING
     518             : static a_routine_ptr lowered_mv_routine(a_routine_ptr routine);
     519             : #endif /* GNU_FUNCTION_MULTIVERSIONING */
     520             : 
     521             : #if GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
     522             : static void change_block_into_statement_expression(a_statement_ptr block);
     523             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
     524             : 
     525             : 
     526             : static void clear_insert_location(an_insert_location      *insert_location,
     527             :                                   an_insert_location_kind kind)
     528             : /*
     529             : Clear an insert location, set its kind to the indicated value, and set
     530             : the associated variant fields to default values.
     531             : */
     532             : {
     533             :   insert_location->kind = kind;
     534             :   switch (kind) {
     535             :     case ilk_after_statement:
     536             :     case ilk_block_start:
     537             :     case ilk_statement_creation:
     538             :       insert_location->variant.statement.stmt = NULL;
     539             :       insert_location->variant.statement.marker = NULL;
     540             :       insert_location->variant.statement.is_marked = FALSE;
     541             :       break;
     542             :     case ilk_before_expr:
     543             :     case ilk_after_expr:
     544             :     case ilk_expr_creation:
     545             :       insert_location->variant.expr = NULL;
     546             :       break;
     547             :     default:
     548             :       unexpected_condition();
     549             :   }  /* switch */
     550             : }  /* clear_insert_location */
     551             : 
     552             : 
     553             : void set_insert_location(a_statement_ptr    stmt,
     554             :                          an_insert_location *insert_location)
     555             : /*
     556             : Set *insert_location to indicate an insert location following stmt.
     557             : Note that stmt must be a statement in a statement sequence (e.g., in
     558             : block); it may not be a statement in a position that requires a single
     559             : statement rather than a sequence (e.g., the dependent statement of an "if").
     560             : */
     561             : {
     562             :   check_assertion_str(stmt != NULL, "set_insert_location: NULL stmt");
     563             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_after_statement);
     564             :   insert_location->variant.statement.stmt = stmt;
     565             : }  /* set_insert_location */
     566             : 
     567             : 
     568             : void set_block_start_insert_location(a_statement_ptr    stmt,
     569             :                                      an_insert_location *insert_location)
     570             : /*
     571             : Set *insert_location to indicate an insert location at the start of
     572             : the block stmt.
     573             : */
     574             : {
     575             :   check_assertion_str(stmt != NULL,
     576             :                       "set_block_start_insert_location: NULL stmt");
     577             :   check_assertion_str(stmt->kind == (a_statement_kind)stmk_block,
     578             :                       "set_block_start_insert_location: stmt not block");
     579             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_block_start);
     580             :   insert_location->variant.statement.stmt = stmt;
     581             : }  /* set_block_start_insert_location */
     582             : 
     583             : 
     584             : void set_statement_creation_insert_location(
     585             :                                            an_insert_location *insert_location)
     586             : /*
     587             : Set *insert_location to a state that allows statement insertion and captures
     588             : the first inserted statement as the base statement.  This is used to create,
     589             : via insertion, a list of statements unattached to the existing IL tree.
     590             : */
     591             : {
     592             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_statement_creation);
     593             : }  /* set_statement_creation_insert_location */
     594             : 
     595             : 
     596             : void set_expr_insert_location(an_expr_node_ptr   node,
     597             :                               an_insert_location *insert_location)
     598             : /*
     599             : Set *insert_location to indicate an insert location before the indicated
     600             : expression node.
     601             : */
     602             : {
     603             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_before_expr);
     604             :   insert_location->variant.expr = node;
     605             : }  /* set_expr_insert_location */
     606             : 
     607             : 
     608             : static void set_after_expr_insert_location(an_expr_node_ptr   node,
     609             :                                            an_insert_location *insert_location)
     610             : /*
     611             : Set *insert_location to indicate an insert location after the indicated
     612             : expression node.  This is a special and tricky mode, and should only be
     613             : used at the top of an expression tree, since it may change the type of
     614             : the node (and it wouldn't be possible to change the types of parent comma
     615             : and question-mark nodes).  The expression must have type void
     616             : or an assignable type.  In the assignable case, the value of the
     617             : original expression is saved in a temporary and then fetched after
     618             : the inserted code has been executed.  Since this changes the
     619             : expression tree, this routine should only be called when it is known
     620             : that an insertion will be made.
     621             : */
     622             : {
     623             :   a_type_ptr       node_type;
     624             :   a_variable_ptr   temp_var;
     625             :   an_expr_node_ptr assign_node, node_copy;
     626             : 
     627             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_after_expr);
     628             :   insert_location->variant.expr = node;
     629             :   node_type = node->type;
     630             :   if (node->result_is_not_used || is_void_type(node_type)) {
     631             :     /* The expression is a void expression.  Nothing special is required. */
     632             :     /* Also true if the expression result is not used. */
     633             :   } else {
     634             :     /* The expression has a non-void type.  Rewrite it to store the value
     635             :        in a temporary, then pick it up later, e.g.,
     636             :          x
     637             :        is rewritten as
     638             :          ((temp = x) , temp)
     639             :        and the insert point is set to insert after the assignment.
     640             :        When x looks like "y != 0", keep the "!= 0" on top, by doing the
     641             :        rewriting under the test:
     642             :          (((temp = y), temp) != 0)
     643             :        This avoids the need to add another "!= 0" later, and avoids some bugs
     644             :        in the Sun cc compiler.
     645             :     */
     646             :     if (is_operation_node(node) &&
     647             :         node->variant.operation.kind == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_ne &&
     648             :         node_operator_type_kind_is(node, tk_integer)) {
     649             :       a_constant_ptr   con = NULL;
     650             :       an_expr_node_ptr first_op = node->variant.operation.operands;
     651             :       an_expr_node_ptr second_op = first_op->next;
     652             :       an_expr_node_ptr other_op = NULL;
     653             :       if (first_op->kind == (an_expr_node_kind)enk_constant) {
     654             :         con = node_constant(first_op);
     655             :         other_op = second_op;
     656             :       } else if (second_op->kind == (an_expr_node_kind)enk_constant) {
     657             :         con = node_constant(second_op);
     658             :         other_op = first_op;
     659             :       }  /* if */
     660             :       if (con != NULL) {
     661             :         /* This is "y != 0" or "0 != y".  Do the transformation on y. */
     662             :         node = other_op;
     663             :         node_type = node->type;
     664             :       }  /* if */
     665             :     }  /* if */        
     666             :     temp_var = make_lowered_temporary(node_type);
     667             :     /* Make a copy of the original node, then assign it to the temporary. */
     668             :     node_copy = copy_node(node);
     669             :     assign_node = make_var_assignment_expr(temp_var, node_copy);
     670             :     /* Change the original node to a comma expression. */
     671             :     assign_node->next = var_rvalue_expr(temp_var);
     672             :     change_node_to_operation(node, (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_comma,
     673             :                              node_type, assign_node, /*is_lvalue=*/FALSE);
     674             :     /* The insert point is after the assignment. */
     675             :     insert_location->variant.expr = assign_node;
     676             :   }  /* if */
     677             : }  /* set_after_expr_insert_location */
     678             : 
     679             : 
     680             : void set_expr_creation_insert_location(an_insert_location *insert_location)
     681             : /*
     682             : Set *insert_location to a state that allows expression insertion and captures
     683             : the first inserted expression as the base expression of the tree.  This is
     684             : used to create, via insertion, an expression tree unattached to the existing
     685             : IL tree.
     686             : */
     687             : {
     688             :   clear_insert_location(insert_location, ilk_expr_creation);
     689             : }  /* set_expr_creation_insert_location */
     690             : 
     691             : 
     692             : void add_to_return_memo_list(a_statement_ptr return_stmt)
     693             : /*
     694             : Allocate a return memo entry to record the existence of the indicated return
     695             : statement, and add it to the list of memo entries.
     696             : */
     697             : {
     698             :   a_return_memo_ptr rmp;
     699             : 
     700             :   check_assertion_str(return_stmt != NULL &&
     701             :                       return_stmt->kind == (a_statement_kind)stmk_return,
     702             :                       "add_to_return_memo_list: bad stmt");
     703             :   if (avail_return_memos != NULL) {
     704             :     /* Reuse a freed entry. */
     705             :     rmp = avail_return_memos;
     706             :     avail_return_memos = rmp->next;
     707             :   } else {
     708             :     /* Allocate a new entry. */
     709             :     rmp = (a_return_memo_ptr)alloc_fe(sizeof(a_return_memo));
     710             : #if DEBUG
     711             :     num_return_memos_allocated++;
     712             : #endif /* DEBUG */
     713             :   }  /* if */
     714             :   rmp->next = return_memo_list;
     715             :   return_memo_list = rmp;
     716             :   rmp->stmt = return_stmt;
     717             : }  /* add_to_return_memo_list */
     718             : 
     719             : 
     720             : void free_return_memo_list(a_return_memo_ptr rmp)
     721             : /*
     722             : Free a list of return memo entries by putting them on the available list.
     723             : */
     724             : {
     725             :   a_return_memo_ptr rmp_next;
     726             : 
     727             :   for (; rmp != NULL; rmp = rmp_next) {
     728             :     rmp_next = rmp->next;
     729             :     rmp->next = avail_return_memos;
     730             :     avail_return_memos = rmp;
     731             :   }  /* for */
     732             : }  /* free_return_memo_list */
     733             : 
     734             : 
     735             : a_dynamic_init_ptr normalize_cleanup_state_for_outer_lifetimes(
     736             :                                               a_dynamic_init_ptr cleanup_state)
     737             : /*
     738             : cleanup_state is a cleanup state limited to the current lifetime, i.e.,
     739             : it's NULL if there are no cleanups in the current lifetime.  Normalize
     740             : it to a cleanup state that isn't limited to the current lifetime,
     741             : and return that.
     742             : */
     743             : {
     744             :   /* The current lifetime can be NULL if there are no lifetimes at all. */
     745             :   if (cleanup_state == NULL && curr_context->lifetime != NULL) {
     746             :     /* No cleanups at this level, so the cleanup state is the position at which
     747             :        the current lifetime fits into the cleanup lists of its parents. */
     748             :     an_object_lifetime_ptr lifetime;
     749             :     for (lifetime = curr_context->lifetime;
     750             :          lifetime != NULL;
     751             :          lifetime = lifetime->parent_lifetime) {
     752             :       cleanup_state = lifetime->parent_destruction_sublist;
     753             :       if (long_lifetime_temps &&
     754             :           lifetime->kind == (an_object_lifetime_kind)olk_block_after_label) {
     755             :         /* When going up into a lifetime preceding a label, in long lifetime
     756             :            temporaries mode, skip temporaries, since they have been
     757             :            destroyed. */
     758             :         while (cleanup_state != NULL &&
     759             :                cleanup_state->has_temporary_lifetime) {
     760             :           cleanup_state = cleanup_state->next_in_destruction_list;
     761             :         }  /* while */
     762             :       }  /* if */
     763             :       while (cleanup_state != NULL &&
     764             :              cleanup_state->destructible_entity_descr != NULL &&
     765             :              ((cleanup_state->overlaps_temps_in_inner_lifetime &&
     766             :                !cleanup_state->destructible_entity_descr->
     767             :                                                         initialization_done) ||
     768             :               cleanup_state->destructible_entity_descr->
     769             :                                is_destruction_for_partial_static_aggregate)) {
     770             :         /* The entity in the parent list is considered to be on the cleanup
     771             :            list only once it has been initialized, and it hasn't been
     772             :            initialized yet.  There can be multiple initializations that
     773             :            overlap with the same inner lifetime with the arrays underlying
     774             :            std::initializer_list objects.  Ignore destructions for
     775             :            partial aggregates of static variables. */
     776             :         cleanup_state = cleanup_state->next_in_destruction_list;
     777             :       }  /* while */
     778             :       if (cleanup_state != NULL) break;
     779             :     }  /* for */
     780             :   }  /* if */
     781             :   return cleanup_state;
     782             : }  /* normalize_cleanup_state_for_outer_lifetimes */
     783             : 
     784             : 
     785             : void set_curr_cleanup_state_to_latest_initialization(void)
     786             : /*
     787             : Set curr_context->curr_cleanup_state to match
     788             : curr_context->latest_initialization.  If the latest initialization pointer is
     789             : NULL, set the current cleanup state to the proper pointer from the parent
     790             : lifetime.
     791             : */
     792             : {
     793             :   curr_context->curr_cleanup_state =
     794             :                           normalize_cleanup_state_for_outer_lifetimes(
     795             :                                           curr_context->latest_initialization);
     796             : }  /* set_curr_cleanup_state_to_latest_initialization */
     797             : 
     798             : 
     799             : void save_and_push_context(a_context              *context,
     800             :                            a_scope_ptr            scope,
     801             :                            an_object_lifetime_ptr lifetime,
     802             :                            a_context              **saved_curr_context)
     803             : /*
     804             : Save the existing context stack in *saved_curr_context, then push the new
     805             : context onto the (now empty) context stack.  This is used in cases where
     806             : "nested full expressions" are needed, for example, when lowering a VLA
     807             : dimension expression within a full expression.  In such cases, its likely that
     808             : a full expression is already being lowered and the VLA dimension expression
     809             : needs to also be treated as a separate, but full, expression so that any
     810             : temporaries generated during the nested full expression are kept separate from
     811             : those in the outer full expression (and aren't released prematurely).  If
     812             : non-NULL, scope and lifetime represent the scope and lifetimes for the new
     813             : context, but typically this is called with those values set to NULL (in which
     814             : case the values from the current context are used).  *saved_curr_context should
     815             : be restored by a later call to restore_saved_context.
     816             : */
     817             : {
     818             :   check_assertion(curr_context != NULL);
     819             :   /* In most cases we're not changing scope or lifetime, so use ones
     820             :      from the current context. */
     821             :   if (scope == NULL) scope = curr_context->scope;
     822             :   if (lifetime == NULL) lifetime = curr_context->lifetime;
     823             :   *saved_curr_context = curr_context;
     824             :   curr_context = NULL;
     825             :   push_context(context, scope, lifetime);
     826             :   /* Save the latest_initialization information from the saved context
     827             :      (it's needed to generate proper destructions in some cases, for example,
     828             :      if there's a branch out of a GNU statement expression). */
     829             :   curr_context->latest_initialization =
     830             :                                   (*saved_curr_context)->latest_initialization;
     831             : }  /* save_and_push_context */
     832             : 
     833             : 
     834             : void restore_saved_context(a_context *context)
     835             : /*
     836             : Restore the context stack specified by *context (as saved by a previous
     837             : call to save_and_push_context).
     838             : */
     839             : {
     840             :   check_assertion(curr_context != NULL && curr_context->parent == NULL);
     841             :   /* Pop the context, then overwrite it with the value from the caller. */
     842             :   pop_context();
     843             :   curr_context = context;
     844             : }  /* restore_saved_context */
     845             : 
     846             : 
     847             : void push_context(a_context              *context,
     848             :                   a_scope_ptr            scope,
     849             :                   an_object_lifetime_ptr lifetime)
     850             : /*
     851             : Add the context entry "context" to the context stack.  The associated scope
     852             : is "scope"; if scope is NULL, curr_context->scope is used.  The associated
     853             : object lifetime is "lifetime"; if lifetime is NULL, the lifetime from the
     854             : scope, or the lifetime from the parent context, will be used.
     855             : */
     856             : {
     857             :   a_context_ptr parent_context = curr_context;
     858             :   a_boolean     new_lifetime;
     859             : 
     860             :   curr_context = context;
     861             :   /* Set the fields. */
     862             :   context->parent = parent_context;
     863             :   /* For the scope, use (1) the parameter passed in, or (2) the scope from
     864             :      the parent context. */
     865             :   if (scope == NULL) scope = parent_context->scope;
     866             :   context->scope = scope;
     867             :   /* For the lifetime, use (1) the parameter passed in, (2) the lifetime from
     868             :      the scope, or (3) the lifetime from the parent context. */
     869             :   if (lifetime == NULL) lifetime = scope->lifetime;
     870             :   new_lifetime = (lifetime != NULL);
     871             :   if (lifetime == NULL && parent_context != NULL) {
     872             :     lifetime = parent_context->lifetime;
     873             :   }  /* if */
     874             :   context->lifetime = lifetime;
     875             :   context->new_lifetime = new_lifetime;
     876             :   /* If this context begins a new object lifetime, set curr_object_lifetime.
     877             :      Also save the old value for restoration by pop_context. */
     878             :   context->saved_curr_object_lifetime = curr_object_lifetime;
     879             :   if (new_lifetime) curr_object_lifetime = lifetime;
     880             :   context->is_function_try_block = FALSE;
     881             :   context->is_generated_routine_context = FALSE;
     882             :   /* The latest_initialization list starts at NULL for a new object lifetime,
     883             :      or is inherited from the parent if there is no new object lifetime. */
     884             :   context->latest_initialization = NULL;
     885             :   if (!new_lifetime && parent_context != NULL) {
     886             :     context->latest_initialization = parent_context->latest_initialization;
     887             :   }  /* if */
     888             :   if (parent_context == NULL) {
     889             :     context->curr_cleanup_state = NULL;
     890             :   } else if (new_lifetime) {
     891             :     set_curr_cleanup_state_to_latest_initialization();
     892             :   } else {
     893             :     context->curr_cleanup_state = parent_context->curr_cleanup_state;
     894             :   }  /* if */
     895             :   context->successor_lifetime_at_statement = NULL;
     896             : #if DO_FULL_PORTABLE_EH_LOWERING
     897             :   context->try_frame = NULL;
     898             : #endif /* DO_FULL_PORTABLE_EH_LOWERING */
     899             :   if (parent_context == NULL || parent_context->scope != context->scope) {
     900             :     /* New scope.  Start a new list of local temporaries and of
     901             :        scopeless compound statements. */
     902             :     context->local_temporaries = NULL;
     903             :     context->scopeless_compound_stmts = NULL;
     904             :   } else {
     905             :     /* Same scope as parent.  Use the same list of local temporaries and of
     906             :        scopeless compound statements. */
     907             :     context->local_temporaries = parent_context->local_temporaries;
     908             :     context->scopeless_compound_stmts =
     909             :                                       parent_context->scopeless_compound_stmts;
     910             :   }  /* if */
     911             : #if CHECKING
     912             :   context->in_full_expression = FALSE;
     913             : #endif /* CHECKING */
     914             : }  /* push_context */
     915             : 
     916             : 
     917             : static void free_temporary_list_entry_list(a_temporary_list_entry_ptr tlep)
     918             : /*
     919             : Free a list of temporary list entries by putting them on the available list.
     920             : */
     921             : {
     922             :   if (tlep != NULL) {
     923             :     /* Find the last entry on the list. */
     924             :     a_temporary_list_entry_ptr tlep_last = tlep;
     925             :     while (tlep_last->next != NULL) {
     926             :       check_assertion(tlep_last->var->init_kind ==
     927             :                                                 (a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_none);
     928             :       tlep_last = tlep_last->next;
     929             :     }  /* while */
     930             :     /* Put the whole list on the front of the available list. */
     931             :     tlep_last->next = avail_temporary_list_entries;
     932             :     avail_temporary_list_entries = tlep;
     933             :   }  /* if */
     934             : }  /* free_temporary_list_entry_list */
     935             : 
     936             : 
     937             : void pop_context(void)
     938             : /*
     939             : Pop an entry off the context stack.
     940             : */
     941             : {
     942             :   a_context_ptr context = curr_context, parent_context = context->parent;
     943             : 
     944             :   if (context->new_lifetime) {
     945             :     /* This context has its own object lifetime, so curr_object_lifetime
     946             :        is restored to what it was at push_context time. */
     947             :     curr_object_lifetime = context->saved_curr_object_lifetime;
     948             :   } else {
     949             :     /* This context does not have its own object lifetime, so the
     950             :        latest_initialization and curr_cleanup_state pointers are propagated
     951             :        up to the parent (they're lifetime-related). */
     952             :     if (parent_context != NULL) {
     953             :       parent_context->latest_initialization = context->latest_initialization;
     954             :       parent_context->curr_cleanup_state = context->curr_cleanup_state;
     955             :     }  /* if */
     956             :   }  /* if */
     957             :   if (parent_context == NULL || parent_context->scope != curr_context->scope) {
     958             :     /* Different scope than parent.  All local temporaries are no longer
     959             :        reusable.  Free the list entries. */
     960             :     free_temporary_list_entry_list(curr_context->local_temporaries);
     961             :     /* Make sure all the scopeless compound statement entries were popped
     962             :        off. */
     963             :     check_assertion(curr_context->scopeless_compound_stmts == NULL);
     964             :   } else {
     965             :     /* Same scope as parent.  Update the parent list of local temporaries. */
     966             :     parent_context->local_temporaries = curr_context->local_temporaries;
     967             :     /* Update the parent list of scopeless compound statements. */
     968             :     parent_context->scopeless_compound_stmts =
     969             :                                         curr_context->scopeless_compound_stmts;
     970             :   }  /* if */
     971             :   /* Pop to the surrounding context. */
     972             :   curr_context = parent_context;
     973             : }  /* pop_context */
     974             : 
     975             : 
     976             : static a_base_class_ptr find_virtual_base_class_of(a_type_ptr derived_class,
     977             :                                                    a_type_ptr virt_base_class)
     978             : /*
     979             : Find the base class entry of derived_type that corresponds to the
     980             : virtual base class virt_base_class (not necessarily a direct base class)
     981             : and return a pointer to the base class entry.  It must be found.
     982             : */
     983             : {
     984             :   a_base_class_ptr virt_bcp;
     985             : 
     986             : #if CHECKING
     987             :   if (!is_immediate_class_type(derived_class)) {
     988             :     internal_error("find_virtual_base_class_of: bad derived_class type");
     989             :   }  /* if */
     990             :   if (!is_immediate_class_type(virt_base_class)) {
     991             :     internal_error("find_virtual_base_class_of: bad virt_base_class type");
     992             :   }  /* if */
     993             : #endif /* CHECKING */
     994             :   for (virt_bcp = derived_class->variant.class_struct_union.
     995             :                                                       extra_info->base_classes;
     996             :        ;
     997             :        virt_bcp = virt_bcp->next) {
     998             : #if CHECKING
     999             :     if (virt_bcp == NULL) {
    1000             :       internal_error(
    1001             :                    "find_virtual_base_class_of: virtual base class not found");
    1002             :     }  /* if */
    1003             : #endif /* CHECKING */
    1004             :     if (virt_bcp->type == virt_base_class && virt_bcp->is_virtual) break;
    1005             :   }  /* for */
    1006             :   return virt_bcp;
    1007             : }  /* find_virtual_base_class_of */
    1008             : 
    1009             : 
    1010             : static a_base_class_ptr find_direct_or_virtual_base_class_of(
    1011             :                                                    a_type_ptr  derived_class,
    1012             :                                                    a_type_ptr  base_class_type)
    1013             : /*
    1014             : Return a pointer to the direct or virtual base class of derived_class with
    1015             : a type identical to base_class_type.  It must be found.
    1016             : */
    1017             : {
    1018             :   a_base_class_ptr  bcp;
    1019             : 
    1020             :   bcp = base_classes_of(derived_class);
    1021             :   for (;;) {
    1022             :     check_assertion(bcp != NULL);
    1023             :     if ((bcp->direct || bcp->is_virtual) && bcp->type == base_class_type) {
    1024             :       /* Found. */
    1025             :       break;
    1026             :     }  /* if */
    1027             :     bcp = bcp->next;
    1028             :   }  /* for */
    1029             :   return bcp;
    1030             : }  /* find_direct_or_virtual_base_class_of */
    1031             : 
    1032             : 
    1033             : static a_field_ptr add_field(char          *field_name,
    1034             :                              a_type_ptr    field_type,
    1035             :                              a_targ_size_t field_offset,
    1036             :                              a_type_ptr    struct_type)
    1037             : /*
    1038             : Make a field with the given type, add it at the right spot in the list of
    1039             : fields attached to struct_type, and return a pointer to the new field.
    1040             : field_name gives the field name (already allocated in the IL memory
    1041             : region).  field_offset gives the byte offset for the field.  The field
    1042             : allocated is not a bit field.
    1043             : */
    1044             : {
    1045             :   a_field_ptr prev_field, next_field;
    1046             :   a_field_ptr field_ptr;
    1047             : 
    1048             :   /* Make the field. */
    1049             :   field_ptr = alloc_field();
    1050             :   field_ptr->source_corresp.name = field_name;
    1051             :   field_ptr->type = field_type;
    1052             :   field_ptr->offset = field_offset;
    1053             : #if IA64_ABI
    1054             :   field_ptr->offset_is_set = TRUE;
    1055             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
    1056             :   field_ptr->compiler_generated = TRUE;
    1057             :   set_class_membership((a_symbol_ptr)NULL, &field_ptr->source_corresp,
    1058             :                        struct_type);
    1059             :   /* Find the spot at which to insert the field. */
    1060             :   for (prev_field = NULL,
    1061             :                next_field = struct_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list;
    1062             :        next_field != NULL && next_field->offset <= field_offset;
    1063             :        prev_field = next_field, next_field = next_field->next) {
    1064             : #if CHECKING
    1065             :     /* Check for fields with the same offset, but watch out for zero-length
    1066             :        fields. */
    1067             :     if (next_field->offset == field_offset &&
    1068             :         next_field->offset_bit_remainder == 0 &&
    1069             :         !field_has_zero_length(next_field)) {
    1070             : #if DEBUG
    1071             :       db_abbreviated_type(struct_type);
    1072             :       fprintf(f_debug, ", offset = %lu, new field = %s, old field = ",
    1073             :                        (unsigned long)field_offset, field_name);
    1074             :       db_name(&next_field->source_corresp);
    1075             :       fputc('\n', f_debug);
    1076             : #endif /* DEBUG */
    1077             :       internal_error("add_field: two fields have the same offset");
    1078             :     }  /* if */
    1079             : #endif /* CHECKING */
    1080             :   }  /* for */
    1081             :   /* Insert the field at the right spot. */
    1082             :   if (prev_field == NULL) {
    1083             :     struct_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list = field_ptr;
    1084             :   } else {
    1085             :     prev_field->next = field_ptr;
    1086             :   }  /* if */
    1087             :   field_ptr->next = next_field;
    1088             :   return field_ptr;
    1089             : }  /* add_field */
    1090             : 
    1091             : 
    1092             : static void add_dummy_field(a_const_char  *field_name,
    1093             :                             a_type_ptr    field_type,
    1094             :                             a_targ_size_t field_offset,
    1095             :                             a_type_ptr    struct_type)
    1096             : /*
    1097             : Make a dummy field with the given type and add it at the right spot in the
    1098             : list of fields attached to struct_type.  field_name gives the field name
    1099             : (not allocated in the IL memory region, i.e., it must be copied).
    1100             : field_offset gives the byte offset for the field.
    1101             : */
    1102             : {
    1103             :   sizeof_t name_length, alloc_length;
    1104             :   char     *name_ptr;
    1105             : 
    1106             :   /* Determine the length of the name. */
    1107             :   check_assertion(field_name != NULL);
    1108             :   name_length = strlen(field_name);
    1109             :   /* Allocate space for the name. */
    1110             :   alloc_length = name_length + 1;
    1111             :   name_ptr = alloc_lowered_name_string(alloc_length);
    1112             :   /* Copy in the name. */
    1113             :   (void)strcpy(name_ptr, field_name);
    1114             :   /* Create the field. */
    1115             :   (void)add_field(name_ptr, field_type, field_offset, struct_type);
    1116             : }  /* add_dummy_field */
    1117             : 
    1118             : 
    1119             : static void add_base_class_dummy_field(a_type_ptr    base_class_type,
    1120             :                                        a_const_char  *field_prefix,
    1121             :                                        a_type_ptr    field_type,
    1122             :                                        a_targ_size_t field_offset,
    1123             :                                        a_type_ptr    struct_type)
    1124             : /*
    1125             : Make a dummy field for a base class or pointer thereto, and add it at the
    1126             : right spot in the list of fields attached to struct_type.  The field name
    1127             : is formed by concatenating field_prefix and the name from base_class_type.
    1128             : field_type gives the type for the field.  field_offset gives the byte
    1129             : offset for the field.
    1130             : */
    1131             : {
    1132             :   sizeof_t    prefix_length, alloc_length;
    1133             :   char        *temp_name, *name_ptr;
    1134             : #if IA64_ABI
    1135             :   a_field_ptr field_ptr;
    1136             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
    1137             : 
    1138             :   /* Build the name for the field.  This is done by combining the
    1139             :      field_prefix and the (possibly mangled) base class name. */
    1140             :   prefix_length = strlen(field_prefix);
    1141             :   /* Develop the (possibly mangled) name. */
    1142             :   /* Note: it *is* necessary to include nested class information on these
    1143             :      names. */
    1144             :   temp_name = mangled_class_name(base_class_type);
    1145             :   /* Allocate space for the whole name. */
    1146             :   alloc_length = prefix_length + strlen(temp_name) + 1;
    1147             :   name_ptr = alloc_lowered_name_string(alloc_length);
    1148             :   /* Copy in the prefix. */
    1149             :   (void)strcpy(name_ptr, field_prefix);
    1150             :   /* Store the base class name. */
    1151             :   (void)strcpy(name_ptr+prefix_length, temp_name);
    1152             :   /* Create the field. */
    1153             : #if IA64_ABI
    1154             :   field_ptr = add_field(name_ptr, field_type, field_offset, struct_type);
    1155             :   if (targ_reuse_tail_padding && is_immediate_class_type(field_type) &&
    1156             :       class_type_supp(field_type)->compiler_generated &&
    1157             :       (field_type->size % field_type->alignment) != 0) {
    1158             :     /* There is padding at the end of the base class subobject in which
    1159             :        derived class members may be allocated. */
    1160             :     field_ptr->base_class_subobject_with_tail_padding = TRUE;
    1161             :   }  /* if */
    1162             : #else /* !IA64_ABI */
    1163             :   (void)add_field(name_ptr, field_type, field_offset, struct_type);
    1164             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
    1165             : }  /* add_base_class_dummy_field */
    1166             : 
    1167             : 
    1168             : static void copy_field(a_field_ptr old_field_ptr,
    1169             :                        a_type_ptr  struct_type,
    1170             :                        a_field_ptr *last_field)
    1171             : /*
    1172             : Make a copy of the field old_field_ptr and add it to the end of the
    1173             : list of fields attached to struct_type.  *last_field points to the
    1174             : last field, or is NULL if there are no fields yet; it is updated
    1175             : on return.
    1176             : */
    1177             : {
    1178             :   a_const_char *field_name;
    1179             :   sizeof_t     name_length, alloc_length;
    1180             :   a_field_ptr  field_ptr;
    1181             : 
    1182             :   /* Copy the name into the file-scope IL memory region. */
    1183             :   field_name = old_field_ptr->source_corresp.name;
    1184             :   /* Watch out for anonymous union fields -- they have no name. */
    1185             :   if (field_name != NULL) {
    1186             :     name_length = strlen(field_name);
    1187             :     alloc_length = name_length + 1;
    1188             :     field_name = strcpy(alloc_lowered_name_string(alloc_length), field_name);
    1189             :   }  /* if */
    1190             :   /* Make the field entry. */
    1191             :   field_ptr = alloc_field();
    1192             :   /* Copy the whole entry, then adjust a few fields. */
    1193             :   *field_ptr = *old_field_ptr;
    1194             :   field_ptr->source_corresp.name = field_name;
    1195             :   field_ptr->source_corresp.parent_scope = 
    1196             :                                     class_type_supp(struct_type)->assoc_scope;
    1197             :   field_ptr->source_corresp.has_associated_pragma = FALSE;
    1198             :   field_ptr->next = NULL;
    1199             :   /* Add the field to the end of the struct field list. */
    1200             :   if (*last_field == NULL) {
    1201             :     struct_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list = field_ptr;
    1202             :   } else {
    1203             :     (*last_field)->next = field_ptr;
    1204             :   }  /* if */
    1205             :   *last_field = field_ptr;
    1206             : }  /* copy_field */
    1207             : 
    1208             : 
    1209             : void make_lowered_field(a_const_char  *field_name,
    1210             :                         a_type_ptr    field_type,
    1211             :                         a_type_ptr    struct_type,
    1212             :                         a_field_ptr   *last_field)
    1213             : /*
    1214             : Make a field with the given name and type and add it to the end of the list
    1215             : of fields attached to struct_type.  The name pointed to by field_name is
    1216             : copied into the file-scope IL memory region.  *last_field points to the
    1217             : last field, or is NULL if there are no fields yet; it is updated on exit.
    1218             : *byte_offset gives the next available position in the structure, both on
    1219             : entry and (updated) on exit.  If struct_type is a union, each field is
    1220             : added at offset 0, and *byte_offset is used to hold the size of the
    1221             : largest field seen so far.  This routine is used for creating fields of
    1222             : wholly-generated structs, not for adding fields to existing structs.
    1223             : It cannot create bit fields.  field_name may not be NULL.
    1224             : */
    1225             : {
    1226             :   sizeof_t                   name_length, alloc_length;
    1227             :   a_field_ptr                field_ptr;
    1228             : 
    1229             :   /* Copy the name into the file-scope IL memory region. */
    1230             :   name_length = strlen(field_name);
    1231             :   alloc_length = name_length + 1;
    1232             :   field_name = strcpy(alloc_lowered_name_string(alloc_length), field_name);
    1233             :   /* Make the field entry. */
    1234             :   field_ptr = alloc_field();
    1235             :   field_ptr->source_corresp.name = field_name;
    1236             :   field_ptr->type = field_type;
    1237             :   field_ptr->compiler_generated = TRUE;
    1238             :   set_class_membership((a_symbol_ptr)NULL, &field_ptr->source_corresp,
    1239             :                        struct_type);
    1240             :   /* Add the field to the end of the struct field list. */
    1241             :   if (*last_field == NULL) {
    1242             :     struct_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list = field_ptr;
    1243             :   } else {
    1244             :     (*last_field)->next = field_ptr;
    1245             :   }  /* if */
    1246             :   *last_field = field_ptr;
    1247             : }  /* make_lowered_field */
    1248             : 
    1249             : 
    1250             : void finish_class_type(a_type_ptr    class_type)
    1251             : /*
    1252             : Finish off a created class type by doing final alignment and storing the
    1253             : size and alignment.  Works for both structs and unions.
    1254             : */
    1255             : {
    1256             :   do_class_layout(class_type);
    1257             : }  /* finish_class_type */
    1258             : 
    1259             : 
    1260             : a_type_ptr void_star_type(void)
    1261             : /*
    1262             : Make and return a "void *" type.
    1263             : */
    1264             : {
    1265             :   return make_pointer_type(void_type());
    1266             : }  /* void_star_type */
    1267             : 
    1268             : 
    1269             : a_type_ptr char_star_type(void)
    1270             : /*
    1271             : Make and return a "char *" type.
    1272             : */
    1273             : {
    1274             :   return make_pointer_type(integer_type(plain_char_int_kind));
    1275             : }  /* char_star_type */
    1276             : 
    1277             : 
    1278             : /*
    1279             : Pointer to the generic function pointer type used in virtual function tables
    1280             : and pointers to member functions, once it is created.  NULL until created.
    1281             : */
    1282             : static a_type_ptr
    1283             :                 vptp_type;
    1284             : 
    1285             : 
    1286             : a_type_ptr make_vptp_type(void)
    1287             : /*
    1288             : Make a type that is used as a generic function pointer in virtual function
    1289             : tables and pointers to member functions if it has not been made already,
    1290             : and return a pointer to it.  The type looks like
    1291             : 
    1292             :   typedef void (*__vptp)();
    1293             : 
    1294             : except that it doesn't actually have a name.
    1295             : */
    1296             : {
    1297             :   a_type_ptr function_type;
    1298             : 
    1299             :   if (vptp_type == NULL) {
    1300             :     /* Make function-of-no-parameters-returning-void. */
    1301             :     function_type = alloc_type((a_type_kind)tk_routine);
    1302             :     function_type->variant.routine.return_type = void_type();
    1303             :     /* Make pointer to function-returning-void. */
    1304             :     vptp_type = make_pointer_type(function_type);
    1305             :   }  /* if */
    1306             :   return vptp_type;
    1307             : }  /* make_vptp_type */
    1308             : 
    1309             : 
    1310             : void add_to_front_of_file_scope_types_list(a_type_ptr type)
    1311             : /*
    1312             : Add the indicated type to the beginning of the file-scope types list.
    1313             : This is used for simple lowering-generated structs that might be used
    1314             : inside other user-written structs.
    1315             : */
    1316             : {
    1317             :   type->next = il_header.primary_scope->types;
    1318             :   il_header.primary_scope->types = type;
    1319             :   /* The in_front_end test deals with cases where this routine is
    1320             :      called from a back end, e.g., when make_typeinfo_type is called
    1321             :      from a back end. */
    1322             :   if (in_front_end && type->next == NULL) {
    1323             :     /* There are no types on the file scope list, so this type is also the
    1324             :        last type on the list. */
    1325             :     curr_translation_unit->file_scope_pointers_block.last_type = type;
    1326             :   }  /* if */
    1327             :   if (parent_scope_of(type) == NULL) {
    1328             :     /* Set the parent scope if it was not already set. */
    1329             :     type->source_corresp.parent_scope = il_header.primary_scope;
    1330             :   }  /* if */
    1331             : }  /* add_to_front_of_file_scope_types_list */
    1332             : 
    1333             : 
    1334             : /*
    1335             : Pointer to the struct type that defines pointers to member functions,
    1336             : once it is created.  NULL until created.
    1337             : */
    1338             : static a_type_ptr
    1339             :                 mptr_type;
    1340             : static a_field_ptr
    1341             :                 mptr_d_field,
    1342             : #if !IA64_ABI
    1343             :                 mptr_i_field,
    1344             : #endif /* !IA64_ABI */
    1345             :                 mptr_f_field;
    1346             : 
    1347             : a_type_ptr make_mptr_type(void)
    1348             : /*
    1349             : Make the struct type used in pointers to member functions if it has not been
    1350             : made already, and return a pointer to it.  Its definition in the Cfront-like
    1351             : ABI is
    1352             : 
    1353             :   struct __mptr { short d; short i; __vptp f; };
    1354             : 
    1355             : "d" is the offset delta, "i" is the index into the virtual function table
    1356             : (or -1 for a nonvirtual function, or 0 for a NULL pointer), "f" is the
    1357             : nonvirtual function pointer or the offset to the virtual table pointer
    1358             : (appropriately cast) for the virtual function case; see ARM 8.1.2c.
    1359             : This type is also used as the entry type in virtual function tables,
    1360             : in the Cfront-like ABI.  There, the "i" field is never needed.
    1361             : (Cfront does it that way, so for compatibility we do too.)
    1362             : 
    1363             : In the IA-64 ABI, the structure is
    1364             : 
    1365             :   struct __mptr { __vptp f; ptrdiff_t d; };
    1366             : 
    1367             : and the "i" field is not used.  The "f" field is 0 for a NULL pointer,
    1368             : is a function pointer for the non-virtual function case, and is the
    1369             : virtual function table index (in bytes) plus 1 for the virtual function
    1370             : case.  The "d" field is the same as for the Cfront-like ABI: it's the
    1371             : adjustment to be added to "this".
    1372             : 
    1373             : When targ_ia64_abi_use_variant_ptr_to_member_function_repr is TRUE, an
    1374             : alternate representation is used (needed for architectures where the address of
    1375             : a function can have the low-order bit set to 1).  The low-order bit of
    1376             : the "d" field indicates whether the function is virtual -- 1 means virtual.
    1377             : The "this" adjustment in the "d" field is shifted left one bit to
    1378             : accommodate this bit.  The "f" field is the same as for the normal
    1379             : IA-64 representation, except that in the virtual function case the
    1380             : index doesn't have one added to it.
    1381             : */
    1382             : {
    1383             :   a_field_ptr   last_field;
    1384             : 
    1385             :   if (mptr_type == NULL) {
    1386             :     /* Make the __mptr struct type.  It doesn't actually have a name. */
    1387             :     mptr_type = make_lowered_class_type((a_type_kind)tk_struct);
    1388             :     add_to_front_of_file_scope_types_list(mptr_type);
    1389             :     last_field = NULL;
    1390             : #if !IA64_ABI
    1391             :     /* field: short d; (delta) */
    1392             :     make_lowered_field("d", integer_type(targ_delta_int_kind), mptr_type,
    1393             :                        &last_field);
    1394             :     mptr_d_field = last_field;
    1395             :     /* field: short i; (index into virtual function table) */
    1396             :     make_lowered_field("i", integer_type(targ_virtual_function_index_int_kind),
    1397             :                        mptr_type, &last_field);
    1398             :     mptr_i_field = last_field;
    1399             : #endif /* !IA64_ABI */
    1400             :     /* field: __vptp f; (pointer to function for nonvirtual case, or
    1401             :        offset to vtbl ptr, appropriately cast, in nonvirtual case) */
    1402             :     make_lowered_field("f", make_vptp_type(), mptr_type, &last_field);
    1403             :     mptr_f_field = last_field;
    1404             : #if IA64_ABI
    1405             :     /* field: ptrdiff_t d; (delta) */
    1406             :     make_lowered_field("d", integer_type(targ_ptrdiff_t_int_kind), 
    1407             :                        mptr_type, &last_field);
    1408             :     mptr_d_field = last_field;
    1409             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */
    1410             :     finish_class_type(mptr_type);
    1411             : #if CHECKING
    1412             :     if (mptr_type->size != targ_sizeof_ptr_to_member_function ||
    1413             :         mptr_type->alignment != targ_alignof_ptr_to_member_function) {
    1414             :       internal_error(
    1415             :  "make_mptr_type: target config of pointer-to-member-function is incorrect");
    1416             :     }  /* if */
    1417             : #endif /* CHECKING */
    1418             :   }  /* if */
    1419             :   return mptr_type;
    1420             : }  /* make_mptr_type */
    1421             : 
    1422             : 
    1423             : a_type_ptr pointer_to_vtbl_type(void)
    1424             : /*
    1425             : Return the type of a pointer to a virtual function table, which
    1426             : is a pointer to an element thereof, i.e., "pointer to const virtual
    1427             : function table entry".  The type is const because virtual function
    1428             : tables are const.
    1429             : */
    1430             : {
    1431             :   a_type_ptr type = make_vtbl_entry_type();
    1432             :   type = make_qualified_type(type, TQ_CONST);
    1433             :   type = make_pointer_type(type);
    1434             :   return type;
    1435             : }  /* pointer_to_vtbl_type */
    1436             : 
    1437             : 
    1438             : a_type_ptr make_virtual_table_table_pointer_type(void)
    1439             : /*
    1440             : Return the type of a pointer to a virtual table table.
    1441             : */
    1442             : {
    1443             :   return make_pointer_type(make_qualified_type(pointer_to_vtbl_type(),
    1444             :                                                TQ_CONST));
    1445             : }  /* make_virtual_table_table_pointer_type */
    1446             : 
    1447             : 
    1448             : a_type_ptr get_underlying_type(a_type_ptr type)
    1449             : /*
    1450             : Drop typerefs, watching out for a typeref with orig_type set.  For that
    1451             : case, return the original type that was rewritten into that typeref.
    1452             : */
    1453             : {
    1454             :   /* Drop typerefs, but look for a special entry that indicates that
    1455             :      it was some other type rewritten by IL lowering. */
    1456             :   while (type->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_typeref) {
    1457             :     if (type->variant.typeref.orig_type != NULL) {
    1458             :       /* A type transformed to something else (e.g., a pointer to
    1459             :          data member changed to a small integer). */
    1460             :       type = type->variant.typeref.orig_type;
    1461             :       break;
    1462             :     }  /* if */
    1463             :     type = type->variant.typeref.type;
    1464             :   }  /* while */
    1465             :   return type;
    1466             : }  /* get_underlying_type */
    1467             : 
    1468             : 
    1469             : a_type_ptr pm_member_type_possibly_lowered(a_type_ptr type)
    1470             : /*
    1471             : type is (or was, before lowering) a pointer-to-member type.  Get and return
    1472             : its member type.
    1473             : */
    1474             : {
    1475             :   a_type_ptr member_type;
    1476             : 
    1477             :   type = get_underlying_type(type);
    1478             :   member_type = pm_member_type(type);
    1479             :   return member_type;
    1480             : }  /* pm_member_type_possibly_lowered */
    1481             : 
    1482             : 
    1483             : a_type_ptr pm_class_type_possibly_lowered(a_type_ptr type)
    1484             : /*
    1485             : type is (or was, before lowering) a pointer-to-member type.  Get and return
    1486             : its class type.
    1487             : */
    1488             : {
    1489             :   a_type_ptr class_type;
    1490             : 
    1491             :   type = get_underlying_type(type);
    1492             :   class_type = pm_class_type(type);
    1493             :   return class_type;
    1494             : }  /* pm_class_type_possibly_lowered */
    1495             : 
    1496             : 
    1497             : a_boolean is_or_was_ptr_to_data_member_type(a_type_ptr type)
    1498             : /*
    1499             : Return TRUE if type is (or was, before lowering) a pointer to data member.
    1500             : The caller must not have skipped any typerefs on the type (as typerefs are used
    1501             : to determine whether the lowered type had a pointer-to-data-member).
    1502             : */
    1503             : {
    1504             :   a_boolean is_ptr_to_data = FALSE;
    1505             : 
    1506             :   type = get_underlying_type(type);
    1507             :   if (is_ptr_to_member_type(type)) {
    1508             :     /* The type is a pointer-to-member type.  See if the member type is
    1509             :        a non-function type. */
    1510             :     if (!is_function_type(pm_member_type(type))) is_ptr_to_data = TRUE;
    1511             :   }  /* if */
    1512             :   return is_ptr_to_data;
    1513             : }  /* is_or_was_ptr_to_data_member_type */
    1514             : 
    1515             : 
    1516             : a_boolean is_or_was_ptr_to_member_function_type(a_type_ptr type)
    1517             : /*
    1518             : Return TRUE if type is (or was, before lowering) a pointer to member
    1519             : function.
    1520             : */
    1521             : {
    1522             :   a_boolean is_ptr_to_func = FALSE;
    1523             : 
    1524             :   type = skip_typerefs(type);
    1525             :   if (type == mptr_type) {
    1526             :     /* The type is the struct used for pointers to members, so this is
    1527             :        a pointer to member function that has been lowered. */
    1528             :     is_ptr_to_func = TRUE;
    1529             :   } else if (is_ptr_to_member_type(type)) {
    1530             :     /* The type is a pointer-to-member type.  See if the member type is
    1531             :        a function type. */
    1532             :     if (is_function_type(pm_member_type(type))) {
    1533             :       is_ptr_to_func = TRUE;
    1534             :     }  /* if */
    1535             :   }  /* if */
    1536             :   return is_ptr_to_func;
    1537             : }  /* is_or_was_ptr_to_member_function_type */
    1538             : 
    1539             : 
    1540             : a_boolean is_ptr_to_member_function_constant_expr(an_expr_node_ptr expr)
    1541             : /*
    1542             : Return TRUE if the indicated (rvalue or lvalue) expression is the lowered
    1543             : version of a pointer to member function constant.
    1544             : */
    1545             : {
    1546             :   a_boolean is_pmf_con = FALSE;
    1547             : 
    1548             :   if (is_variable_node(expr)) {
    1549             :     a_variable_ptr var = node_variable(expr);
    1550             :     if (!has_name(var) &&
    1551             :         /* Variables for constants are initialized.  Temporaries are not. */
    1552             :         var->init_kind == (an_init_kind)initk_static &&
    1553             :         is_or_was_ptr_to_member_function_type(var->type)) {
    1554             :       is_pmf_con = TRUE;
    1555             :     }  /* if */
    1556             :   }  /* if */
    1557             :   return is_pmf_con;
    1558             : }  /* is_ptr_to_member_function_constant_expr */
    1559             : 
    1560             : 
    1561             : #if !PROMOTE_LOCAL_ENTITIES_TO_FILE_SCOPE
    1562             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* <--- promote_if_necessary is not used in that case. */
    1563             : #endif /* !PROMOTE_LOCAL_ENTITIES_TO_FILE_SCOPE */
    1564             : void add_temporary_to_scope(a_variable_ptr temp,
    1565             :                             a_scope_ptr    scope,
    1566             :                             a_boolean      promote_if_necessary)
    1567             : /*
    1568             : Add the indicated temporary variable to the variables list of the indicated
    1569             : scope.  If scope is NULL, use the nearest enclosing scope.  If
    1570             : promote_if_necessary is TRUE, the temporary is immediately promoted to file
    1571             : scope if the temporary is static and statics have already been promoted out of
    1572             : the enclosing routine.  Generally speaking, promote_if_necessary should be
    1573             : set to FALSE if the temporary represents something added by the compiler
    1574             : (e.g., exception handling tables), and TRUE if it represents something
    1575             : in the user's program.
    1576             : */
    1577             : {
    1578             :   if (scope == NULL) {
    1579             :     a_scopeless_compound_stmt_ptr scsp;
    1580             :     /* Determine the nearest enclosing scope. */
    1581             :     scope = curr_context->scope;
    1582             :     /* We may be able to take a scopeless compound statement inside the
    1583             :        nearest existing scope and add a scope to it. */
    1584             :     scsp = curr_context->scopeless_compound_stmts;
    1585             :     if (scsp != NULL &&
    1586             :         /* Don't create scopes for local static variables, because that
    1587             :            makes it too hard to figure out the scope to use when
    1588             :            calling make_local_static_variable_init later. */
    1589             :         !var_has_static_or_thread_storage_duration(temp)) {
    1590             :       a_statement_ptr stmt = scsp->stmt;
    1591             :       a_block_ptr     block = stmt->variant.block.extra_info;
    1592             :       if (block->assoc_scope != NULL) {
    1593             :         /* This statement has already had a scope added to it, so use that. */
    1594             :         scope = block->assoc_scope;
    1595             :       } else if (block->implicit_scope_not_allowed) {
    1596             :         /* This block doesn't allow implicit addition of a scope. */
    1597             :       } else {
    1598             :         /* If the nearest scope has subscopes we don't try to add a scope,
    1599             :            because it's a little difficult to figure out where the new scope
    1600             :            should go in the list of subscopes.  Likewise for pragmas. */
    1601             :         if (scope->scopes == NULL && scope->pragmas == NULL
    1602             : #if MINIMAL_INLINING
    1603             :             /* Don't add the scope if the current routine is inline, because
    1604             :                having block scopes disqualifies a routine for inlining. */ 
    1605             :             && !innermost_function_scope->variant.routine.ptr->is_inline
    1606             : #endif /* MINIMAL_INLINING */
    1607             :                                                                         ) {
    1608             :           /* We have a compound statement we can use.  Add the scope. */
    1609             :           a_scope_ptr parent_scope = curr_context->scope;
    1610             :           scope = alloc_scope((a_scope_kind)sck_block,
    1611             :                               take_next_scope_number(),
    1612             :                               (a_routine_ptr)NULL);
    1613             :           block->assoc_scope = scope;
